State Center for Research and Development of Oil Shale Exploitation, Sinopec Beijing 100083 China Oil shale is a promising unconventional energy source whose processed oil products exhibit a H/C ratio comparable to that of crude oil. This study introduced a purely organic acid-base bifunctional porous material, HCP-BBA-S, and conducted a comprehensive investigation of its catalytic performance in the hydrothermal pyrolysis of oil shale under near-critical water conditions. Upon incorporation of the HCP-BBA-S catalyst, shale oil yield increased by 4.61–19.22 %, accompanied by a shift in oil composition towards lower carbon numbers and lower boiling points. Oxygen content in the products decreased significantly, improving oil quality and calorific value. Under optimized conditions, shale oil yield reached 41.85 %, with an H/C atomic ratio of 1.8 and a calorific value of 41.42 MJ/kg. These results highlight HCP-BBA-S as a highly effective catalyst for enhancing both the yield and quality of shale oil, offering a sustainable approach to unconventional energy resource utilization. In response, the exploration and development of unconventional oil and gas resources have rapidly advanced worldwide, becoming a crucial component of the oil and gas supply system [2]. Oil shale, as a potential alternative energy source, has garnered considerable attention due to its extensive geological reserves, high technical development challenges, and significant development potential [3–5].Oil shale is a fine-grained combustible sedimentary rock containing a large amount of immature organic matter and high ash content. It is primarily composed of inorganic minerals and macromolecular organic matter known as kerogen, with minor amounts of free bitumen [6]. The pyrolysis process, which involves heating oil shale to high temperatures, can produce bitumen and pyrolysis gas. The bitumen migrating from the oil shale matrix is termed shale oil, which is the primary target product during extraction [7,8]. In-situ oil shale extraction technology involves directly heating the oil shale reservoir buried underground, causing the solid kerogen within to decompose into light oil and gas. These products are then extracted to the surface through traditional oil and gas wellbores [9,10]. This method offers advantages such as a small surface footprint, low development costs, minimal environmental impact, and the ability to develop deep oil shale resources, making large-scale exploitation of oil shale resources feasible [11]. However, current in-situ extraction techniques are energy-intensive and exhibit low energy efficiency. The appropriate addition of catalysts can effectively lower the pyrolysis temperature of kerogen, enhance in-situ conversion efficiency, and improve oil quality [12]. Hyne and Clark [13] were the first to propose using transition metal salts as catalysts, decomposing heavy oil components into alkanes, CO2, H2S, H2, and other small molecular products, thereby achieving oil upgrading. Presently, research on oil shale catalytic pyrolysis primarily utilizes transition metal salts and inorganic solid acid catalysts. However, liquid acids and metal salts tend to cause permeability pollution, while inorganic solid catalysts show negligible effects due to their poor oleophilicity. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop new catalysts that are efficient, environmentally friendly, and economically viable. Hyper-crosslinked porous polymers (HCPs) have demonstrated significant potential in the field of heterogeneous catalysis due to their high surface area, abundant active sites, excellent stability, and environmentally friendly characteristics [14–16]. Additionally, HCPs are easily customizable; their performance can be enhanced by introducing functional groups or active sites [17]. For instance, the PDVB-SO3H catalyst, obtained by treating porous polydivinylbenzene (PDVB) with a strong oxidizing agent (ClSO3H), exhibited superior catalytic performance in a series of esterification and acylation reactions compared to traditional commercial solid acids Amberlyst-15 and β-zeolite [18]. This superior performance is primarily attributed to the high concentration of sulfonic acid groups and the porous framework structure of the catalyst. Wang and colleagues [19]synthesized porous organic polymers via cross-coupling and Yamamoto coupling reactions, anchoring palladium nanoparticles on them to produce Pd@CPP-C and Pd@CPP-Y catalysts, which exhibited excellent olefin hydrogenation catalytic performance. Similarly, Bhaumik [20] designed and synthesized the hyper-crosslinked polymer HMP-1, which, after sulfonation, yielded the highly acidic HMP-1-SO3H material. This material demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance in esterification and transesterification reactions, especially in converting free fatty acids (FFA) into biodiesel. Although there have been no reports of metal-free purely organic catalysts in oil shale catalytic conversion applications, numerous studies suggest that catalysts with porous structures and acid-base active sites exhibit significant potential in the catalytic cracking of heavy hydrocarbons, comparable to that of metal catalysts [21,22]. This study proposes an innovative method for in-situ upgrading of oil shale using HCPs modified with acid and base functionalities. Based on the synthesis of amino group-containing HCP-BBA, sulfonic functional groups are introduced through chemical modification to prepare the dual-function acid-base catalyst HCP-BBA-S. This catalyst is employed to catalyze the in-situ hydrocracking of oil shale. The functional groups -SO3H and -NH2 serve as acid and base activation centers, respectively, facilitating various reactions such as hydrolysis, dehydration, isomerization, decarboxylation, and hydrocracking. These reactions promote the catalytic cracking of heavy hydrocarbons in oil shale, thereby enhancing the yield of hydrocarbons. This method offers a promising new approach for clean energy production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Benzene, benzylamine, ethyl acetate, sodium bicarbonate, and methanol were obtained from Aladdin (Shanghai China)；Chlorosulfonic acid and sodium chloride were obtained from Sinopharm (Shanghai China)；Anhydrous ferric chloride, dimethoxymethane, dichloromethane, 1,2-dichloroethane, and pyridine were s obtained from Meryer (Shanghai China)； Hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide were obtained from Dingsen (Shanghai China). All reagents and solvents used are of analytical grade and require no further purification. 2.2 Oil shale preparation The oil shale used in this study was sourced from the Maoming Dianbai mining area in China, with an oil content of 5.58 % and a TOC of 12.1 %. Detailed information of other basic characterization tests is provided in the SI. The oil shale blocks were crushed and ground, then sieved to 50–100 mesh according to the requirements of different tests. The 100 g of oil shale powder, after sieving, was stirred in 300 mL of deionized water for 30 minutes and then soaked for 4 hours. It was subsequently washed 3–5 times with 100 mL of deionized water until the water became clear after washing. The solid was then vacuum-dried at 35°C for 24 hours and sealed for further use. 2.3 Catalysts preparation HCP-BBA was synthesized using a simple and efficient external cross-linking method. In a round-bottom flask, 50 mL of DCE, 1.6643 mL of benzene, and 0.6825 mL of benzylamine were added sequentially and stirred in an ice bath for 30 minutes. After the ice bath, 6.08 mL of dimethoxymethane (FDA) as a cross-linking agent and 11.15 g of anhydrous FeCl3 as a catalyst were added. The mixture was stirred magnetically under a nitrogen atmosphere at room temperature for 30 minutes. The temperature was then raised to 45°C and the mixture was stirred for an additional 5 hours to form a preliminary cross-linked network. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 80°C and the mixture was continuously stirred for 19 hours.After the reaction was complete, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the solid product was washed several times with methanol. The solid product was then subjected to Soxhlet extraction with methanol for 24 hours. Following this, the product was basified with a 10 % NaHCO3 solution for 24 hours and washed several times with distilled water, followed by filtration. Finally, the solid product was vacuum-dried at 80°C to obtain a light brown powder, HCP-BBA. The HCP-BBA-S catalyst was prepared by sulfonating HCP-BBA. In a round-bottom flask, 0.5 g of HCP-BBA was added along with 15 mL of DCE and allowed to swell for 3 hours. Subsequently, under an ice-salt bath, 10 mL of DCM containing chlorosulfonic acid (0.25 mL) was slowly added dropwise using a constant-pressure funnel. The mixture was stirred continuously under a nitrogen atmosphere at 50°C for 4 hours. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled and quenched by pouring it into a large amount of ice water. The product was washed several times, filtered, and then subjected to Soxhlet extraction with methanol for 24 hours. The final product was vacuum-dried overnight at 60°C to obtain a dark gray powder, HCP-BBA-S-0.5. The resulting acid-base functionalized organic porous polymers were denoted as HCP-BBA-S-x (where x = 0.15, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2.5, and 5), with x representing the ratio of chlorosulfonic acid volume (mL) used in the sulfonation step to the mass of HCP-BBA (g) ( Fig. 1). 2.4 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (77 K) of the catalysts were measured using a physical adsorption instrument (BSD-PM2). The specific surface area and pore size parameters of the catalysts were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. Pore size distribution was determined using non-local density functional theory (NLDFT). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR; BRUKER TENSOR27, scanning range 4000 cm⁻¹ to 500 cm⁻¹) was employed to analyze the functional groups and structural changes of the catalysts. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; Quanta 250, acceleration voltage: 5 kV) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS; acceleration voltage: 20 kV) was used to observe the high-resolution morphology and surface element distribution of the catalysts. The thermal stability of the catalysts was determined using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; TG 209) within the temperature range of 50–750°C. The total acidity of the prepared catalysts was measured by back titration. 2.5 Oil shale pyrolysis Using the optimized HCP-BBA-S-0.5 as the catalyst, the oil shale powder/kerogen samples were mixed uniformly with the catalyst at a 10:1 ratio and evenly distributed on an alumina crucible to ensure effective pyrolysis. A control experiment was also set up, where only the oil shale powder/kerogen samples were evenly distributed on the alumina crucible without any catalyst. Both sets of samples were heated from room temperature to 800°C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TG 209). 2.6 Oil shale in-situ catalytic conversion In a 50 mL reactor, 4 g of oil shale powder, 0.4 g of catalyst, and 10 mL of H2O were added sequentially and stirred to mix uniformly before sealing the reactor. According to IUPAC classification [23], these catalysts fall into the category of microporous materials. Fig. 2a illustrates the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of these catalysts, showing typical Type I curves. Each isotherm exhibits a steep increase in nitrogen adsorption at low pressures (P/P₀ < 0.001), indicating the presence of abundant microporous structures (<2 nm). As the pressure increases, the adsorption capacity levels off in the moderate pressure range, showing distinct hysteresis loops, which suggests the presence of mesopores (2–50 nm). The sharp rise at high pressures indicates the presence of macropores. Fig. 2b presents the pore size distributions of HCP-BBA and HCP-BBA-S-0.5 obtained through NLDFT theoretical analysis, further confirming the presence of micropores and mesopores in these catalysts. The pore size distribution results indicate that HCP-BBA primarily features pores centered at 0.34, 0.65, 2.13, and 33 nm, while HCP-BBA-S-0.5 shows predominant pores at 0.34, 0.38, 0.67, 0.73, 2.21, and 33 nm. Catalysts with different sulfonation levels exhibit varying specific surface areas and acidities, as shown in Table 1. With increasing sulfonation, the specific surface area of the catalysts decreases gradually from 1043 m²/g for pristine HCP-BBA to 340 m²/g, accompanied by a reduction in total pore volume. This decrease in specific surface area and pore volume can be attributed to the increased presence of pendant functional groups that partially fill the pores. Despite the decrease in overall surface area and specific micropore area, there is a proportionate increase in the specific micropore area. From a catalytic perspective, studies have shown that high surface area alone does not solely determine catalytic efficiency. Synergistic effects between functionalization and high surface area are more conducive to enhancing catalyst activity [24–25]. Additionally, the hierarchical pore structure in HCP-BBA-S enhances mass transfer efficiency between liquid and solid phases, thereby improving catalytic activity. Macropores and mesopores facilitate the transport of reactants and products, while micropores can function as efficient microreactors [26]. The acidity of the catalysts was determined using acid-base titration, as shown in Table 1. Typically, as the amount of chlorosulfonic acid used in the sulfonation process increases, the acidity of HCP-BBA-S-x also increases. Particularly for x < 0.5, the total acid content and moderate acid content of the catalyst increase rapidly, confirming the introduction of -SO₃H groups that form numerous Brønsted acid sites within the HCP network [24]. However, as the chlorosulfonic acid amount increases (x > 0.5), the rate of increase in total acid content slows down. This may be due to the maximum or saturated grafting capacity of HCPs, where only phenyl rings exposed on the pore surfaces can accommodate sulfonic acid groups. Even with excessive acid treatment, saturation of acid sites may be observed. The decrease in acidity observed for HCP-BBA-S-5 could be attributed to the excessive chlorosulfonic acid leading to partial pore blockage and damage, resulting in reduced surface area and acid site density. FTIR spectroscopy reveals the chemical composition of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, the absorption peaks at 2917 cm⁻¹ and 2903 cm⁻¹ for HCP-BBA and HCP-BBA-S correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of -CH₂-. Peaks at 1600 cm⁻¹ , 1500 cm⁻¹ , and 1450 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the aromatic ring skeletal vibrations, indicating that sulfonation did not alter the fundamental structure of the original polymer. Additionally, HCP-BBA-S exhibits characteristic absorption peaks for sulfonic groups at 1682 cm⁻¹ , 1198 cm⁻¹ , 1037 cm⁻¹ , and 605 cm⁻¹ , which are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of OS=O. The weak peak at 1091 cm⁻¹ is ascribed to the C(aromatic)-S stretching vibration, confirming the successful incorporation of sulfonic acid groups into HCP-BBA-S. The broad and strong absorption band between 3100 cm⁻¹ and 3700 cm⁻¹ is associated with the stretching vibrations of -OH and -NH₂ groups, suggesting that the catalyst retains amino groups while incorporating sulfonic acid groups. FTIR spectroscopy thus confirms the successful synthesis of HCP-BBA-S with both acidic and basic functional groups. Through FE-SEM observation, the morphology and microstructure of original HCP-BBA and six sulfonated catalysts were examined, as depicted in Fig. 4. The original HCP-BBA (Fig. 4a) exhibits characteristics of nano-porous structure, forming irregular agglomerated nanoparticles with a diameter of ∼20 nm. These nanoscale particles interact closely and aggregate into worm-like structures, consistent with typical hyper-crosslinked polymer morphology [17]. Additionally, Fig. 4b-f reveal that the nano-porous structure of HCP-BBA-S undergoes noticeable partial collapse, induced by the sulfonation treatment with chlorosulfonic acid. Furthermore, with increasing sulfonation degree, HCP-BBA-S gradually exhibits a layered structure. This morphological change could be attributed to changes in polymer hydrophilicity, corresponding to the decrease in surface area post-sulfonation. These morphological transformations align with previous findings [27]. EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 4g, h) demonstrates the uniform distribution of N and S elements within the catalysts, indicating successful fixation of -NH2 and -SO3H groups on the surface of HCPs materials. The extensive hyper-crosslinked framework likely contributes to the highly robust properties of HCPs, including chemical and thermal stability. Thermal stability analysis of HCP-BBA and sulfonated HCP-BBA-S-0.5 was conducted using TG curves, as shown in Fig. 5. The initial slight weight loss during the heating stage is attributed to the desorption of water. Additionally, the significant weight loss observed for HCP-BBA-S between 400 and 500°C is likely due to the decomposition of sulfonic acid groups and partial degradation of the polymer framework. Both polymers exhibit thermal stability in N₂ atmosphere up to temperatures as high as 350°C, surpassing many reported sulfonated porous carbon catalysts [28–29] and the commercial polymer solid acid Amberlyst-15 (250°C) [18]. TG analysis demonstrates that both HCP-BBA and HCP-BBA-S possess excellent thermal stability, ensuring the preservation of required mass transfer pores during catalytic processes without collapsing even at elevated temperatures. This characteristic makes them highly promising for acid-catalyzed reactions under demanding conditions. 3.2 Catalytic conversion of oil shale A high surface area and well-sulfonated HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst was selected for the catalytic hydrothermal pyrolysis of oil shale. The resulting shale oil products were analyzed under both catalytic and non-catalytic conditions using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). Fig. 6 compares the carbon number distribution of the hydrothermal pyrolysis products with and without the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst. The results indicate that the addition of the catalyst shifts the carbon number distribution towards a lower range. This shift suggests that the abundant acid and base sites in the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst significantly enhance the cracking of long-chain hydrocarbons, leading to a higher yield of short-chain carbon products. Saturated hydrocarbons, aromatic hydrocarbons, oxygen-containing compounds (alcohols, esters, phenols, aldehydes), and nitrogen-containing compounds are common components in oil shale conversion products, with saturated and aromatic hydrocarbons being predominant [30]. Fig. 7 presents a comparison of the shale oil product composition with and without the catalyst. It is evident that under catalytic conditions, the content of saturated hydrocarbons significantly increases, by 14.4 %, compared to the non-catalytic products. Meanwhile, the content of oxygen-containing and nitrogen-containing compounds decreases by 6.6 % and 2.5 %, respectively. The increase in saturated hydrocarbons is mainly attributed to the catalytic decarboxylation, decarbonylation, or hydrodeoxygenation pathways. The acid and base sites of the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst facilitate the cracking of long-chain carbon substances and promote deoxygenation reactions, thereby reducing the content of oxygen-containing compounds. The increase in saturated hydrocarbon content and the reduction in oxygen content enhance the energy value of the shale oil products [31–32]. To conduct pyrolysis kinetic studies aimed at determining the activation energy and reaction rate of the process, we examined the thermal conversion characteristics of oil shale and kerogen using TG curves under fixed heating rates [33–35]. Using HCP-BBA-S-0.5 as a catalyst, we investigated the pyrolysis characteristics of oil shale and kerogen samples both with and without the catalyst. This research provides fundamental data for optimizing the design and operation of the thermal chemical catalytic conversion process of shale oil. Fig. 8 presents the thermogravimetric (TG) and derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curves for the pyrolysis of oil shale and kerogen.The pyrolysis process of oil shale can be primarily divided into three stages: a slight weight loss at low temperatures (50–200°C) mainly due to the evaporation of moisture in the samples; a significant weight loss at high temperatures (400–600°C) attributed to the decomposition of organic matter [36], with a weight loss rate of 17.83 %, accounting for 62.76 % of the total weight loss; and a minor weight loss at ultra-high temperatures (700–900°C) resulting from the pyrolysis of inorganic matter and fixed carbon. Compared to the low and high-temperature stages, the thermal decomposition process in the ultra-high-temperature stage is not as pronounced. Considering the actual temperature conditions in industrial applications, the final temperature of the TG experiment was set at 800°C.The pyrolysis process of kerogen is similar to that of oil shale but exhibits an earlier and larger weight loss peak, reflecting its higher organic content. Table 2 lists the relevant parameters for the primary pyrolysis interval (400–600°C) of the four samples. Within this temperature range, the organic components in oil shale convert into bitumen, which then gradually decomposes to produce oil, gas, and other products. This stage is also where large molecular organic compounds, such as kerogen, undergo pyrolysis to generate shale oil and shale gas [37–38]. According to the data in the table, the samples with the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst exhibit a noticeable shift in the initial temperature, final temperature, and temperature corresponding to the maximum weight loss rate during the main pyrolysis stage. This indicates that the catalyst can lower the activation energy of the pyrolysis reaction for oil shale and kerogen, enabling pyrolysis to occur at lower temperatures. This finding provides strong support for improving the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of industrial applications. 3.3 Influence of sulphonation degree on the effectiveness of catalytic conversion of oil shales The effects of HCP-BBA-S catalysts with different degrees of sulfonation on the hydrothermal cracking and upgrading of oil shale were compared. According to Fig. 9, the yield of oil shale conversion products is significantly influenced by the catalyst. Without a catalyst, the oil yield is 22.63 %, whereas the addition of catalysts increases the yield to between 27.24 % and 41.85 %. Among these, the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst exhibits the highest oil yield, followed by HCP-BBA-S-2.5, HCP-BBA-S-0.75, HCP-BBA-S-5, HCP-BBA-S-0.2, and HCP-BBA-S-0.15, in that order. The optimal catalyst, HCP-BBA-S-0.5, increases the oil yield of the oil shale sample to 41.85 %, which is an improvement of 19.22 % compared to the yield without any catalyst. In the Fig. 9, the blue line represents the acidity of each catalyst, and the presence of acidic sites facilitates various reactions such as hydrolysis, dehydration, and hydrocracking. Notably, hydrocracking mainly occurs at Brønsted acid sites [39]. Sulfonated catalysts, due to their relatively high number of Brønsted acid sites, enhance the cracking of long carbon chains, thereby increasing the yield of shale oil. However, the results indicate that there is no strict positive correlation between oil yield and total acidity. This is because heterogeneous catalysis involves multiple factors: a high specific surface area of the catalyst provides numerous reactive sites, and the micropores within the catalyst allow the bitumen to enter and undergo sequential pyrolysis reactions [40–41]. Therefore, in addition to maintaining the acidity of the catalyst, achieving a high surface area and appropriate pore size is crucial for the efficient hydrothermal cracking of oil shale.This underscores the importance of catalyst design, which must possess not only the necessary chemical properties but also physical properties that enhance the catalytic conversion process. For instance, although HCP-BBA-S-2.5 and HCP-BBA-S-5 have higher acidity, their lower specific surface areas result in less effective oil production compared to HCP-BBA-S-0.5. Fig. 10 and Table 3 illustrate the impact of various catalysts on the carbon number distribution of oil shale conversion products. The carbon number of pyrolysis products mainly ranges from C6 to C27, with a concentration between C12 and C17. Compared to the conversion products without a catalyst, the HCP-BBA-S-0.15, HCP-BBA-S-0.5, and HCP-BBA-S-5 catalysts significantly increase the content of C5-C11 by 3–8 %, and all catalytic conversion products show a notable reduction in the content of carbon numbers greater than C20. This indicates that the abundant acidic and basic sites in the catalysts can effectively convert large molecules into smaller ones. The boiling point distribution is typically used to reflect the relative content of light and heavy components in petroleum products. Fig. 11 and Table 4 present the boiling point distribution data of shale oil products. Compared to shale oil products obtained without a catalyst, the catalytic processing of oil shale results in a shift of product composition towards light fractions such as gasoline and middle distillates (low boiling points), while the heavy fractions with boiling points above 350°C (such as vacuum gas oil and residual oil) are significantly reduced. Using HCP-BBA-S-0.15, HCP-BBA-S-0.5, and HCP-BBA-S-2.5 catalysts increases the content of products with boiling points in the range of 100–200°C by 1.9–8.6 %. These results can be attributed to the synthesized acid-base bifunctional porous catalysts, which possess abundant acidic and basic sites with strong hydrocarbon conversion capabilities. Long-chain alkanes are cracked into short-chain alkanes at these acidic sites, thus increasing the proportion of light hydrocarbons and converting heavy oil into light oil. This transformation demonstrates the effectiveness of HCP-BBA-S catalysts in refining shale oil products, enhancing the yield of more valuable light fractions. 3.4 Elemental analysis and calorific value of shale oil composition Table 5 lists the elemental composition and heating value data of shale oil after catalytic conversion. Compared to the original oil shale samples, the oxygen content in the upgraded shale oil significantly decreases (from 3.61 % to 1.64 %), while the carbon and hydrogen contents notably increase (from 85.22 % to 86.28 % and from 10.39 % to 12.79 %, respectively). Particularly with the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst, the H/C atomic ratio of the product increases to 1.80, and the O/C atomic ratio decreases to 0.019. Additionally, the high heating value (HHV) of the shale oil reaches 41.42 MJ/kg, which is a 16 % improvement compared to the unprocessed oil shale. Fig. 12 displays a Van-Krevelen diagram based on the H/C and O/C ratios of the products, illustrating the impact of different catalysts on the quality of shale oil conversion products. The presence of Brønsted acid and basic sites facilitates deoxygenation reactions, promotes dehydration of fatty alcohols, and enhances hydrogenation isomerization and hydrocracking of alkanes in the products, thereby reducing the oxygen content and significantly improving the quality of the oil products [42–43]. Typically, the H/C atomic ratio in petroleum products ranges from 1.6 to 2.0. The shale oil products from hydrothermal cracking without catalysts notably do not meet this standard. However, products catalyzed by HCP-BBA-S-x (x > 2) exhibit H/C atomic ratios within this standard range. This characteristic indicates that these catalysts effectively facilitate deoxygenation and hydrogenation processes in oil shale, making them suitable for producing high-quality shale oil products using hydrothermal cracking technology. 4 Conclusions In this study, we successfully applied the HCP-BBA-S series catalysts for the catalytic conversion of oil shale under simulated in-situ conditions, achieving a significant increase in shale oil yield, with the highest observed increase being 19.22 % compared to the absence of a catalyst under identical conditions. Analysis of the product composition indicates that the acidic active sites on the catalyst surface effectively promote the cracking of long carbon chains, directing shale oil components towards lower carbon numbers and lower boiling points. Furthermore, the catalysts demonstrate significant effectiveness in enhancing oil quality, with catalytically upgraded shale oil showing increased carbon and hydrogen contents (from 85.22 % to 86.28 % and from 10.39 % to 12.79 %, respectively), and a notable decrease in oxygen content (from 3.61 % to 1.64 %). Particularly, under the influence of the HCP-BBA-S-0.5 catalyst, shale oil yield reaches its peak (41.85 %), accompanied by excellent H/C atomic ratio (1.8) and high heating value (41.42 MJ/kg). These results firmly establish the crucial role and feasibility of acid-base organic porous catalysts in the hydrothermal cracking process of oil shale, providing new technological pathways and theoretical support for the clean utilization of oil shale. coredata.dc:description: Oil shale is a promising unconventional energy source whose processed oil products exhibit a H/C ratio comparable to that of crude oil. This study introduced a purely organic acid-base bifunctional porous material, HCP-BBA-S, and conducted a comprehensive investigation of its catalytic performance in the hydrothermal pyrolysis of oil shale under near-critical water conditions. Upon incorporation of the HCP-BBA-S catalyst, shale oil yield increased by 4.61–19.22 %, accompanied by a shift in oil composition towards lower carbon numbers and lower boiling points. Oxygen content in the products decreased significantly, improving oil quality and calorific value. Under optimized conditions, shale oil yield reached 41.85 %, with an H/C atomic ratio of 1.8 and a calorific value of 41.42 MJ/kg. These results highlight HCP-BBA-S as a highly effective catalyst for enhancing both the yield and quality of shale oil, offering a sustainable approach to unconventional energy resource utilization.
